title: High Bar, High Reward
pros: I’ve been at Ventas for just over two years now, and I’ve seen this company shift from good to truly great. When I first joined, there was energy and ambition — lots of “we can do more” — but more recently I feel like we’ve found our stride. The leadership isn’t just chasing growth; they’re being very intentional about how we grow, where we invest, and making sure we build sustainable advantage. For a large S&P 500 company, the corporate team is surprisingly small and nimble. You actually see the outcome of your work and feel connected to what’s happening at the top. There’s not a lot of red tape — people focus on the work and on doing it well. The pace can be quick and priorities can shift, but that comes with being in a company that’s looking ahead instead of playing catch-up — and that’s a good place to be.
cons: It’s a small, high-performing team with nowhere to hide. Accountability starts at the top — the CEO can and will dive into details. If you aren’t excellent at what you do, this probably isn’t the place for you.

title: An organized workplace that treats its employees well
pros: Good pay, great healthcare benefits, great boss, hybrid work
cons: Other departments seemed to suffer from overwork, but my assigned work was reasonable

title: Ventas
pros: Great place to work, greta culture
cons: No cons at the moment

title: Fine
pros: Surrounded by intelligent and curious people
cons: Hours and poor org structure

title: Job Culture
pros: Your work provides value to the group. The office environment is great, with tons of free food. Company is always growing.
cons: Workload is overwhelming sometimes and the company will not slow down for your team to catch up or grow. Expect extra hours to offset the growth mindset. Promotions typically are external and internal growth is limited (expect to boomerang).

title: Good place to begin a career
pros: Good benefits, my team had good chemistry
cons: Workaholic culture, a lot of turnover

title: Love my job
pros: Amazing work perks. Awesome people to work with and plenty of growth opportunities
cons: Busy and can sometimes be high stress.

title: Not Recommended
pros: Pay is good for position and great benefits
cons: Complete and total lack of work life balance. As well as absolutely no opportunities for growth and development. If you decide to work for them then make sure you are happy with the job title and the salary offered. While they do provide small annual salary increases it doesn’t do enough to compensate for lack of career growth. There are some nice managers here, but overall leadership is clueless when it comes to helping their employees grow and develop in the company. Considering that this is a vital part of leadership I would consider the leadership at the company extremely poor. They don’t have the first clue when it comes to true leadership. It doesn’t matter how hard or long you work for them there is absolutely zero effort by them to help you succeed. When a job comes open they’ll fill from someone outside the company. They don’t even bother looking at internal candidates. Companies with good leadership helps their employees to grow and develop within the organization. Don’t be fooled by the salary! It’s a trap. Go to a company with clear strategies for growth and development. The salary may be lower initially, but in 3-5 you’ll be way better off.

title: Employment Review
pros: Good opportunities for internal growth
cons: Multiple levels of reviews for necessary approvals

title: Ventas
pros: Colleagues, location, flexibility, diversity, pay
cons: Micro management, work life balance

title: Hardworking with Great Culture
pros: Opportunities to align with professional interests Strong internal promotion pathways Comprehensive benefits package
cons: Some late nights / fire drills Top down management

title: Okay
pros: Great company with many good people.
cons: Some teams are not good and are very rude. Some teams are overworked

title: Great place to work
pros: Focused and dedicated employees with strong team approach
cons: Year end work can be challenging

title: Micromanagement and Bad Work-Life Imbalance
pros: Competitive pay compared to other companies
cons: Working at Ventas feels like an endless 24/7 commitment, with little consideration for personal time or boundaries. Since my start, I've found myself working on most weekends, nights, vacations, and even during flights for work-related tasks. The oppressive culture of micromanagement is deeply rooted within my team. My managers exhibit an incessant need to oversee every minor task, going as far as reviewing my emails before I can even send them out. This level of oversight leaves little room for independent decision-making and stifles any potential for professional growth. For those considering a position at this company, it's essential to be aware of the high turnover rate. A cursory LinkedIn search is likely to reveal a string of predecessors in the role you're eyeing. I would strongly advise reaching out to them and asking questions to gain a better understanding of what you may be getting into.

title: Compensated workaholism
pros: Great compensation and telework Monday and Friday.
cons: Atmosphere in the company is workaholism. If you’re try to only do 40 hours, lower management will judge you.

title: Not Worth The Battle
pros: Exposure to corporate finance/real estate, tenured real estate professionals, great health benefits
cons: Career advancement heavily dependent on if you are liked by leadership vs. merit/overall work product. CEO laid off 25% of workforce via an 8am emailed video saying to expect a call from a manager by 11am if you'd be part of the layoff - during the peak of the pandemic a couple weeks after preaching a "commitment to our people" Lack of strategic direction from executive management team - very reactive. Every minor decision needs to be touched/seen by executive team - no autonomy/trust even on senior level employees. Below average pay with false promises of promotions/advancement. Lack of leadership commitment to develop entry to mid-level employees and no focus on retention & keeping good talent. Retention efforts led to money being thrown at some employees (highly discriminatory on who received awards) Lack of accountability for poor people management - exodus of employees yet no real change at the top based off employee feedback. Culture is non-existent; fire drill mentality for non-issue items. Peppered with non-purposeful engagement events - employees are in silos in their respective departments even though its a relatively small company. No recognition - thank you is non-existent The leader/manager above is always right and do not welcome collaborative point of views. Starts at the top with the CEO; taboo to challenge opinions and views.

title: Hybrid Work Environment
pros: The entire company is on the same hybrid schedule. 2 days remote, 3 days in the office.
cons: Sometimes very cliquish for a company.

title: Fantastic place
pros: Great benefits Great culture Great pay
cons: None that I can think of

title: Ctrl Alt Delete
pros: Decent benefits; pretty offices; many loyal, hardworking employees
cons: The company is resting on its laurels. The executives love to tout the company’s long term performance but the real outperformance occurred years ago - just look at a stock chart. The dirty secret is that the leadership hasn’t done anything valuing enhancing in years. The CEO is a masterful deal maker, but has surrounded herself with sycophants and yes men and gets involved in every minor decision. The executives slap each other on the backs and hoard oversized pay, while the next layers of employees do all the real work and provide the creative ideas, with little credit. Serious talent has walked out the door, new hires rarely stick, and those tenured employees that have stayed have become too damaged from years of mind games to know any better. The HR function is out of step and focuses mostly on spinning employee engagement results to look positive.

title: Great learning opportunity...the rest varies
pros: - Great place to learn and grow professionally; something is always happening and with small teams you'll get exposure to a lot - You'll work with lots of interesting, intelligent people - Management access; there aren't a lot of multi-billion dollar industry leaders where you'll get to interact with C-level folks - Tight knit culture where it's easy to make friends
cons: - Work life balance varies between below average and awful; some groups are really bad but it also varies a lot depending on the manager you work with - Career progression is a black box and sometimes a black hole; nobody knows what it takes to advance or when that might reasonably happen. Might be waiting a while with little feedback in the meantime - Pay skews very top heavy

title: It’s all about the culture
pros: Smart colleagues, dynamic work, company is financially able to provide resources and tools and movement between departments is supported.
cons: Top heavy; executive leadership involved in too many decisions for a large firm; boys club mentality; hostile / overly aggressive leaders; expectations often unreasonable

title: Successful company with hard working, driven and caring employees
pros: Successful company, well regarded female CEO, competitive compensation, excellent benefits, collaborative employees, challenging and rewarding work, good tools and resources, training and development opportunities
cons: Work environment can sometimes be intense but what successful, publicly traded company isn't similar? Lack of established flexible work guidelines is problematic for managers who feel like they have to have permission to run off road. In departments where managers effectively manage, flexibility isn't an issue.

title: Anonymous
pros: - Challenging and meaty work - Smart, driven, fun colleagues - Interesting and dynamic industry - Growing company that pushes into new sectors - Lots of movement internally into different positions, groups, and levels - Compensation, other rewards for hard work
cons: - Work/life balance can suffer at times from drive for responsiveness - There is no clear cut career path, which can make it difficult for employees to understand their next move

title: Large company with small company feel - limited career growth
pros: For being a company with great size, the culture is close knit and small. There is good access to senior leadership and the decision makers. Company throws twice annual parties for employees and has internal networking events. Office space and amenities are top-notch.
cons: Minimal work-life balance, as an employee you are always "on call". Senior leadership does not respect your personal life or any paid time off. Although they want to promote work-life balance you are rarely able to attend any of the hosted events without a huge backlog of work. Very minimal career path and growth opportunities.

title: Great Company
pros: Working at Ventas has provided me with many tools for success. This is a company that will bring out the best as they want all employees to strive toward excellence. You are well rewarded for meeting goals set before you.
cons: Long hours are expected to be worked at the office or at home. Deadlines can sometimes seem unattainable, especially if you are unable to work extra hours. Some departments can feel understaffed. Moving up within the company can be difficult. There isn't much turn-over and unless there are large acquisitions positions do not come open often.

title: Great professional experience
pros: Great benefits, lots of smart colleagues. One thing I truly appreciate about Ventas is their capabilities and willingness to invest in their employees by encouraging them to learn more. I am thankful for the opportunities given to me to expand my knowledge and the help of the management teams to push me to be better, while taking all the blame if appropriate.
cons: Very tightly run so workloads can stack up due to the overbearing work performed on routine portfolio management. Would like to work on more interesting projects. Thus, work life balance can suffer depending on the portfolio. Pay could be a bit better.

title: Honestly a great place to work
pros: I've been at ventas for more than 4 years and honestly have to say that I'm shocked at some of the negative reviews. However, I do know that the pros/cons definitely are shaped by thier department and reporting managers. I personally want to congratulate Ventas on the job they did during the pandemic. Management was on the forefront and well ahead of the curve and although we lost 25-30% of the company in May of 2020, they were extremely transparent on the cuts and why and I couldn't be more proud of how they have adapted "post-pandemic". In the professional world there will always be deadlines, lots of work on the plate, however I've found that working closely with your manager to prioritize and set expectations on delivery solves 99% of the issues. They are always providing training opportunities, open to hearing new ideas and always looking for ways in increase efficiency. They heavily invest in their employees and after 20 years in the professional work force, Ventas is top notch.
cons: There appears to be vast differences in managment styles between departments which really can impact how an employee feels. If you have great leadership in your department this will be a very rewarding place to work. However, on the flip side, If leadership in your department isn't so great it sounds like it could be very challenging to those that are not used to a fast pace evolving environment.

title: Weak culture, high turnover, proceed with caution
pros: - Office has nice views - Market comp to play in Excel all day due to limited resources to invest in financial reporting technology
cons: - Weak leadership that limits growth potential - Finance organization has high turnover because of this - Bureaucratic organization that's top heavy with leadership and not enough heads to do the actual work demands - Non value-added work content and responsibilities - Traditional, old school culture

title: Stay Away
pros: Friendly people and flat organizational structure make for easy collaboration and good exposure to senior leadership.
cons: Sweatshop culture with consistent 60+ hour weeks make for exhausting work experience. Expect frequent weekend disruptions, interruptions on vacation if you’re able to take one, and emails at all times of day. May offer a 5–10% better salary vs. market but you’ll pay for it with 25% more hours.

title: Sweatshop - depending on team
pros: Good culture/exposure. High level performers.
cons: Drastic imbalance of workload depending on the team you are on. Certain team(s) require almost constant prioritization of work over anything else in your life, which has caused very high levels of turnover. Imagine that.

title: Tread Lightly - Toxic, Backstabbing, and Incompetent Culture
pros: Entry level jobs provide some good exposure Positive outlook on the CEO Good people below Manager title
cons: No word describes this company more than Toxic - specifically the finance and AM teams If you dont fit some certain undefined criteria, you stand no chance Incompetent HR department that has no care for the internal communication issues Leadership lacks vision Compensation below average "Promises" are not kept, specifically as it relates to promoting talent within. Primary reason for such high turnover

pros: robust benefits package, exposure to challenging work, collaborative environment, compensation/bonus, female CEO, access to training/development/feedback
cons: work-life balance, no ability to work from home, lack of diversity
